author: Ishiguro, Kazuo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: These modern novels drive me mad. They take some “unique” hypothetical – like some of us are clones or we live on the moon – something that’s easily uThese modern novels drive me mad. They take some “unique” hypothetical – like some of us are clones or we live on the moon – something that’s easily understood from the back jacket description, and then they write a BORING ASS BOOK around it. No depth! No complexity! No subtlety! Every point driven by “What I really mean by that is…” and every transition is “Now I really want to tell you…” - choices that you would get you a C- in high school. Someday these authors will realize that setting only gets you so far. Could I do better? Nope. Do I think this qualifies as literature? Nope....more

review: Steinbeck is my guy. He’s a realist, I’m a realist. He’s the North Star I point to when I say, “I like those kinds of authors.” And yet Grapes of WratSteinbeck is my guy. But I can’t quit you, John Steinbeck! You break my heart with these stories of hunger, exhaustion, and longing for dignity. I did not have fun reading this book but it did everything it was made to do. review: (3.5) The Master and Margarita is a high speed chase through surrealism and social critique. Nearly impossible to summarize, Bulgakov manages to weave(3.5) The Master and Margarita is a high speed chase through surrealism and social critique. Nearly impossible to summarize, Bulgakov manages to weave three stories into one: 1) the literal devil and his cronies pranking Moscow into chaos, 2) Pontius Pilot’s experience during the trial of Jesus, and 3) two long-lost lovers hoping to reunite. Though often confusing both in subject matter and intent, M&M was also delightfully absurd and rich with slapstick interactions. Exactly the kind of novel you appreciate more after you’ve finished and read other commentary about the story, the Soviet Union, and the author. I could see myself enjoying it much more on a second read....more

title: Jayber Crow

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I learned a lot from sitting with old Jayber Crow. He let me listen while he lowered my ears and shaved me clean. At times, in my stubborn youth, I thI learned a lot from sitting with old Jayber Crow. He let me listen while he lowered my ears and shaved me clean. At times, in my stubborn youth, I thought it might be time to go, but I’m glad I stayed. His chair is comfortable.“Often what has looked like a straight line to me has been a circle or a doubling back. I have been in the Dark Wood of Error any number of times. I have known something of Hell, Purgatory, and Heaven, but not always in that order. The names of many snares and dangers have been made known to me, but I have seen them only in looking back. Often I have not known where I was going until I was already there. I have had my share of desires and goals, but my life has come to me or I have gone to it mainly by way of mistakes and surprises. Often I have received better than I have deserved. Often my fairest hopes have rested on bad mistakes. I am an ignorant pilgrim, crossing a dark valley. And yet for a long time, looking back, I have been unable to shake off the feeling that I have been led — make of that what you will.”...more

review: Hard Rain Falling doesn’t have a clever plot or a big conclusion. It’s a grim portrait of a flawed man trying to survive in an unloving world. It’s raHard Rain Falling doesn’t have a clever plot or a big conclusion. It’s a grim portrait of a flawed man trying to survive in an unloving world. It’s raw, insightful prose that rarely resolves and often stings. I’m not eager to revisit the content, but whatever I’m reading next will make me miss Don Carpenter’s writing. I can’t believe this was published in ‘66. Looking back, this is a writer’s novel. You don’t stay for plot, character redemption, suspense, or any other shiny thing. title: Either/Or
author: Batuman, Elif
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: (2.5/5) Either/Or let me down. Having enjoyed The Idiot (with a few caveats), I had hopes that Either/Or would build on my appreciation for Batuman’s (2.5/5) Either/Or let me down. Having enjoyed The Idiot (with a few caveats), I had hopes that Either/Or would build on my appreciation for Batuman’s writing and the world she was building around Selin. That didn’t happen. The first 2/3 of the novel was aimless wallowing over the events of the previous book. The self-reflections droned on and the pace became infuriating. In the last third of the book, Selin makes choices that – to me – don’t match her character. Nor do they open the door to some unexplored territory of her mind. They just happen, with the same meaninglessness as her other anecdotes. I suppose there’s value in a character that doesn’t fit the reader’s mold, but it all felt out of place. Batuman’s a fantastic, clever writer, no doubt, but this story felt hardly worth telling. Any given part could’ve been left out and change little of the end result. I’m perhaps overly critical because I see so much potential in Batuman’s writing; I’m rooting for her, though now I’m more hesitant to follow her future work....more

review: An easy recommendation for someone interested in short stories. George’s writing is unique in that it’s very stream-of-consciousness from each narratoAn easy recommendation for someone interested in short stories. George’s writing is unique in that it’s very stream-of-consciousness from each narrator’s perspective. You get every thought, no matter how weird or incoherent. This makes the first few pages of each story hard to get into because you don’t have context for their world yet, but by the end the plot holes get patched up and those thoughts add up to characters you feel surprisingly familiar with after a few short pages. Maybe not my favorite style, but it works and Saunders has mastered it....more

review: Kafka on the Shore is like a dream you wake up from and struggle to explain. Some moments are mundane, others are surreal fantasy, and they blend perfKafka on the Shore is like a dream you wake up from and struggle to explain. Some moments are mundane, others are surreal fantasy, and they blend perfectly together. The plot is nonsense. You wake up with more questions than answers and it’s easy to forget what got you so worked up in the first place. But when you’re in it, man! It feels real! 5 stars for Murakami’s writing. -1 star for some weird sex stuff....more

review: I’m not a horror guy or a Stephen King guy, but this book was undeniably good. If you can get past the gruesome premise (essentially an R rated hungerI’m not a horror guy or a Stephen King guy, but this book was undeniably good. If you can get past the gruesome premise (essentially an R rated hunger games), you’ll find rich character development, witty dialogue, and a look into adolescent friendship that parallels classics like Stand by Me and the Sandlot. Sure, there’s a lot about mortality too, and a few weird parts, but this book has depth. I wish everyone could read it without the violence being a barrier to entry. ...more

author: McCarthy, Cormac

review: I respect it, but didn’t enjoy it. I get why it’s on lists and that McCarthy gives lit nerds plenty to discuss; he shows you everything but tells you I respect it, but didn’t enjoy it. I get why it’s on lists and that McCarthy gives lit nerds plenty to discuss; he shows you everything but tells you nothing. Still, the first 75% was a slog through violence and convoluted desert descriptions. In the end, the themes may have been brilliantly crafted but they just weren’t themes I cared about. Maybe I’ll read this again when I’m 50 and see it in a new light....more
